title: 112_hr6565
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a concise summary of the section's title and its findings. The "LIFT HIGHER Act of 2012" aims to address the financial barriers that prevent students from pursuing graduate education. It highlights the increasing student loan debt, application fees, and costs associated with exams and preparation courses. The Act recognizes the rising percentage of Americans with graduate degrees and the higher earning potential for individuals with advanced degrees. Persons with advanced degrees earn significantly more in their lifetime compared to those with bachelor's degrees. Highly educated citizens are crucial for the national interest, and university education is the most effective way to gain professional skills and training. A new section, SEC. 36C, introduces a refundable tax credit for graduate school application expenses in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This credit aims to support individuals pursuing advanced degrees, emphasizing the importance of highly educated citizens for the national interest. A tax credit is allowed for qualified graduate school application expenses paid by a specified applicant during the taxable year. The credit is limited to $500 minus any previous credits claimed and is also subject to limitations based on modified adjusted gross income. The tax credit for qualified graduate school application expenses is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with specific thresholds for individual and joint filers. The tax credit for qualified graduate school application expenses is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with specific thresholds for individual and joint filers. A specified graduate school applicant is defined as an individual applying to an eligible educational institution for a program leading to a graduate degree. Qualified expenses include application fees, test fees, and study materials. The text discusses the eligibility criteria for a tax credit for graduate school application expenses, including expenses for study materials and tutorial services for tests. Additionally, it mentions that no credit is allowed for individuals who can be claimed as dependents by another taxpayer. Conforming amendments are also made to related sections of the tax code. Paragraph (2) of section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended by inserting "36C," after "36B,". The table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended accordingly. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.
